image.altText: A child's hand written card saying 'dear mum, I think you are great'.

props.synopsis: A social worker at a child contact centre has alleged key players in a family court case ignored her concerns about the possible abuse of a four-year-old girl.

title.children: Joan told her manager at a child contact centre she was worried 4yo Sally might be being abused. She was later fired

image.altText: A man in a green polo shirt sits on a chair

props.synopsis: Paul Dowden has had shingles three times, and says it is ''the worst pain" he's experienced. He's urging people to get vaccinated, but as demand "far exceeds" supply in the ACT, that is easier said than done.

title.children: Paul says shingles caused 'the worst pain' he's felt, but getting a vaccine is not simple

image.altText: A busy pedestrian crossing at the intersection of Spencer and Collins streets in Melbourne's CBD.

props.synopsis: Data from the OECD shows Australia recorded the biggest increase to average tax rates in the developed world last year due to bracket creep and the end of a tax offset, but a separate report finds Australia is still a relatively low-taxing nation.

title.children: Australia's tax rate increase was the biggest in the world last year, and those on lower incomes paid the price

image.altText: Weinstein laughs on the red carpet of the Golden Globes after party in 2014.

props.synopsis: Weinstein's successful appeal is a blow to the #MeToo movement against powerful men who prey on vulnerable women. And a New York judge warns it's set a precedent that will help serial sexual predators.

title.children: Harvey Weinstein's rape conviction has been quashed. Here's why, and what happens next

image.altText: Cutouts of two Aboriginal girls over a picture of an empty road in the desert.

props.synopsis: On a road out the back of Bourke, the lives of two Indigenous teenage girls ended in 1987. They were failed by the police as the lawyer for the defendant played on racial tensions in the town.

title.children: ‘Predatory and disgraceful’: The man who plied teens with alcohol before doing the unthinkable

image.altText: A young man poses for a photo on a cliff face, with mountains behind him.

props.synopsis: Ben Cohen, who was falsely identified as the person behind the Bondi Junction stabbing attack by the Seven network, has settled his defamation case.

title.children: Man misidentified as Bondi Junction attacker by Seven settles defamation case with the network

image.altText: two brumbies walking along in long grass within a national park

props.synopsis: The program will be halted pending an investigation after hundreds of horse carcasses, including brumbies, were allegedly found on a property near Wagga Wagga.

title.children: NSW suspends brumby rehoming after discovery of hundreds of dead horses

image.altText: A man walks next to a girl who stares at him adoringly with a hand on his chest

props.synopsis: The elevation of Kim Jong Un's female relatives coincides with the growing economic and social power of women living inside secretive North Korea.

title.children: 'You have to be agile and pivot': Kim keeps showing off his daughter — and it may be for his own survival

image.altText: A container with brown food.

props.synopsis: Eureka Group is one of Australia's largest providers of independent living units for seniors. But tenants are having to spend 80 per cent of their age pension on rent just to live there.

title.children: Seniors' village operator boasts 'chef'-prepared food in justifying rent rise. But some residents challenged that

image.altText: An orange BHP logo on a grey background.

props.synopsis: The ASX is trading lower on Friday, with BHP shares dropping by 4 per cent after confirming its $60 billion takeover bid for Anglo American, while the latest US PCE data has reduced  the chance of rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. Follow live.

title.children: BHP shares fall after $60b takeover bid for Anglo American, Mike Cannon-Brookes becomes Atlassian's sole CEO

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Australia's average tax rate increase was the biggest in the OECD last year
The report that gave Crown Melbourne the green light

image.altText: close up of side of Scott Morrison's face

props.synopsis: Former prime minister Scott Morrison reveals his experiences with acute anxiety while serving as the nation's leader, saying it is a conversation that should be normalised in federal politics.

title.children: Scott Morrison says he took medication for anxiety as prime minister

image.altText: bushfire burns in distance

props.synopsis: An emergency warning is in place as a bushfire burns in "parched" bushland near Western Australia's south coast, north-east of the town of Walpole.

title.children: Emergency warning issued as 'deliberately lit' bushfire threatens WA properties

image.altText: Indonesian fishermen wave at the camera from a fishing boat

props.synopsis: The latest government data shows another spike in foreign fishing boats coming close to shore, with residents describing Indonesian boats painted green in a bid blend into mangrove creeks.

title.children: Foreign boat numbers surging as 'cat and mouse' game intensifies on northern coast

props.synopsis: It's time to test your knowledge about the news of the week.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: A breastfeeding row, a celebrity snail, plus Prince Louis's birthday

image.altText: A yellow spotted goanna eating a black whip snake.

props.synopsis: Snakes and lizards in the Australian outback are locked in a battle of survival. Which is predator and which is prey comes down to strategies they've evolved to resist deadly venom, a study suggests.

title.children: Think snakes are scary? These lizards have evolved to make snakes the snack

image.altText: A placard at a march saying 'I can't believe we still have to march, women are being killed!'

props.synopsis: Our leaders agree that violence against women is a national crisis — an emergency. But a national emergency requires an emergency response.

title.children: Australia shouldn't tolerate terrorism — but our normalisation of 'intimate partner terrorism' has become a national emergency

image.altText: Former US President Donald Trump looks on inside a New York courtroom.

props.synopsis: Former National Enquirer publisher David Pecker testifies at Donald Trump's criminal trial that he wrangled with Mr Trump and his former lawyer ahead of the 2016 election over who should buy the silence of women who said they had sexual encounters with him.

title.children: National Enquirer publisher says he wrangled with Donald Trump over who should buy sex stories

image.altText: Young woman having injection inserted into cheek by hands wearing white plastic gloves.

props.synopsis: The TGA wants to protect vulnerable Australians from cosmetic enhancement advertising. But some warn new guidelines could cause more problems.

title.children: The TGA is cracking down on cosmetic injectable ads. Vapes and Ozempic are partly to blame

image.altText: A teenager on their phone.

props.synopsis: ASIO chief Mike Burgess says there has been a rise in the number of minors identified in his counterterrorism caseload. The "vulnerable cohort" has increased again, and the question now is who they are, how they get radicalised, and what Australia can do to prevent it.

title.children: 'We shouldn't be calling children terrorists': How young people get radicalised

image.altText: Mass housing site

props.synopsis: Brisbane Lord Mayor Adrian Schrinner has hit out at plans to turn the controversial Pinkenba quarantine facility into a police training centre rather than repurposing it for the homeless.

title.children: Controversial Pinkenba quarantine facility to be repurposed by Australian Federal Police

image.altText: Missing woman Jessica Zrinski smiling while sat in a car

props.synopsis: The NSW Homicide Squad begins a second search for missing Sydney woman Jessica Zrinski around the Jenolan Caves area in the NSW Central Tablelands.

title.children: Homicide detectives scour Jenolan Caves bushland for signs of missing woman Jessica Zrinski

image.altText: A photo of a Sydney wharf in daylight

props.synopsis: NSW Police has confirmed that an unidentified body of a man in his 50s was found in Pyrmont.

title.children: Body found floating in waters near Pirrama Wharf in Sydney Harbour

image.altText: A man with a long beard wears a suit, sunglasses and an Islamic cap as he walks into a court building, surrounded by reporters.

props.synopsis: An influential former Islamic State supporter who was released from a supervision order last year was questioned in Wednesday's police raids on an alleged terrorism network involving a group of Sydney boys.

title.children: Influential alleged former IS member Wassim Fayad raided in Sydney counter-terror blitz

image.altText: Queen Mary and King Federick of Denmark smile standing sude by side wearing royal attire.

props.synopsis: The official gala portrait of King Frederik and Australian-born Queen Mary shows her wearing the crown jewels for the first time since ascending the throne in January.

title.children: First official portrait of King Frederik and Queen Mary of Denmark released

image.altText: Harvey Weinstein dressed in a suit, sitting in a court room

props.synopsis: New York’s highest court finds that the judge at the landmark #MeToo trial prejudiced the ex-movie mogul with “egregious” improper rulings.

title.children: New York appeals court overturns Harvey Weinstein’s 2020 rape conviction from #MeToo trial

image.altText: A woman standing outside on a footpath, smiling.

props.synopsis: 2.9 million people with HECS-HELP debt will be hit by an increase of 4.7 per cent when their debts are indexed on June 1st, but there are calls for massive change.

title.children: Universities review chief calls for HECS debt 'gremlins' to be cleaned out

image.altText: The Chinese flag waves in front of a flag with the Olympic rings on it.

props.synopsis: An investigation led by a Swiss prosecutor will look into how the World Anti-Doping Agency handled positive doping tests of 23 Chinese swimmers in the lead-up to the Tokyo Olympic Games.

title.children: 'WADA's reputation is under attack': Independent review to look into handling of Chinese swimmers' positive doping tests

image.altText: Eleven students, women and men, sit in a group looking at the camera.

props.synopsis: The country collects more in HECS repayments annually than it does in tax from oil and gas — and experts say changing that could pay down the HECS debt within three years.

title.children: When these uni students don their graduation gowns, they'll collectively owe more than $750,000 in HECS debt

image.altText: East Kimberley landscape pictured from the air by police.

props.synopsis: Travellers set to explore one of northern Australia's most renowned tourist destinations are being urged to properly prepare for remote travel as vast areas welcome visitors for the dry season.

title.children: Outback chopper rescue prompts warnings for tourists heading to wild, unforgiving remote areas

image.altText: A film still of Hoa Xuande, a Vietnamese Australian man with a distressed expression, holding a burning letter.

props.synopsis: Ever since the revered director's first English-language project Stoker, Park Chan-wook has managed to successfully translate his tragicomic style across new formats. His latest triumph is miniseries The Sympathizer.

title.children: It took 30 years for Hollywood to give Park Chan-wook a TV blockbuster. It's some of his best work

image.altText: Grey-headed Flying Fox mother and pup with distinctive ruff around neck and chest.

props.synopsis: Grey-headed flying foxes move into new locations in search of food and habitat, and their defenders say residents need to learn to live with the sometimes noisy and smelly creatures.

title.children: Flying foxes are coming to a town near you, and experts say we need to learn to live with them

props.synopsis: A pink Moon rises, baby otters meet the public for the first time, a rare white squirrel is spotted playing in a Beijing park and China hosts an amazing sand sculpture competition — it's been another busy week across the vast Asia Pacific region.

title.children: Baby otters' first public outing, Japan's royals host a garden party — the Asia Pacific this week in 20 photos
